Notarial instrument, narrating that, according to the altogether laudable custom of the burgh of Ayr, beyond memory of man, it had been judicially proved, in three head Courts of the burgh, that a certain tenement therein, belonging to the late Alan Boyman, and lying between the tenement of the late Andrew Legate on the one side, and that of William Williamson on the other, was waste, abandoned, and thrown to the ground, on account of the non-payment of eight shillings Scots of annualrent due from the same to the prior and convent of the Friars Preachers of the said burgh, and that it had been adjudged in a fourth Oourt held in the court-house of the said burgh, after the lapse of forty days 3116. 111010 from the public proclamation thereos, by the mouth of John Boyl, burgess, dempster sworn in the said Oourt‚ that the same tenement ought to be given by state and sasine, for the‘reasons foresaid, to the said prior and convent for ever; and after these things had been lawfully declared and duly performed the said Court was dissolved: Thereafter, Stephen Preston, one of the bailies of Ayr, gave state, heritable sasine, and corpora] possession of the said tenement to friar John Litstare‚ prior of the Friars Preaohers, craving judgment thereupon in the name of the whole convent.
